awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Tri-functional (feeding, venting, sensing) tube for premature infants
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a tri-functional (feeding, venting, and sensing) tube for premature infants. The long-term health of children born prematurely is a major national and international concern. Each year more than 15 million infants globally, and 350,000 infants in the US are born prematurely. High-quality clinical research has driven huge advances in prenatal care and allowed intervention to become the standard of care at gestations that were considered incompatible with survival just 20-30 years ago. Infants born at 22-23 weeks of gestation, weighing 400-500 grams are now routinely admitted for intensive care intervention. Respiratory failure remains the primary cause of mortality and morbidity in extremely premature newborns, yet physiologic monitoring of respiratory status has not advanced since the introduction of oxygen saturation monitoring in the 1980s. The proposed tri-functional tube may provide value by continuously monitoring vital signs while simultaneously feeding and venting the extremely preterm infant in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), avoiding the need for skin-mounted sensors, which are an irritant to newborn skin and produce unreliable readings due to poor contact. Current healthcare costs to society potentially may be reduced using this tri-functional tube technology.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a tri-functional (feeding, venting, and sensing) tube for premature infants. This technology integrates three functionalities for the first time: delivering milk feeds to the stomach, venting excess gas from the stomach (a by-product of non-invasive modes of ventilation), and multifunctional vital sign monitoring such as electrocardiogram (ECG), transdiaphragmatic pressure, and body core temperature. The tri-functional tube design has evolved through multiple iterations based on clinical needs and engineering input. Extensive literature and product reviews, as well as testing results, have defined optimal sensor locations and configurations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Participation in the NSF National I-Corps Program offered a unique opportunity for the team behind the Trinity Tube to engage deeply in customer discovery, a critical step towards understanding the multifaceted needs of the neonatal intensive care market. The Trinity Tube, a revolutionary neonatal feeding tube capable of delivering milk, venting excess gas, and monitoring vital signs like ECG, transdiaphragmatic and airway pressure, and core temperature, addresses critical clinical needs in the care of extremely preterm infants. Given the device's innovative integration of feeding, venting, and sensing functionalities, the I-Corps Program provides an essential platform for validating the product-market fit through immersive learning and hands-on experience. This experience is vital for refining the Trinity Tube's value propositions, particularly in a sensitive and complex care environment like the NICU, where the long-term health of premature infants is paramount. By engaging directly with healthcare professionals, patients, and other stakeholders, the program enables the Trinity Tube team to uncover nuanced insights into the clinical workflow, regulatory requirements, and the broader impact of their device on neonatal care. This customer-centric approach not only enhances the development process but also significantly contributes to the successful commercialization and adoption of the Trinity Tube, ultimately leading to improved outcomes for one of the most vulnerable patient populations.

Throughout the NSF National I-Corps Program, the Trinity Tube team engaged in an extensive customer discovery process. This involved interviewing a wide array of healthcare professionals, including neonatologists, NICU nurses, neonatal nurse practitioners, respiratory specialists, and medical device subject matter experts, across various prestigious institutions and organizations. The participants ranged from those at ground-breaking medical centers like Stanford Medicine Children's Health, Dell Children’s Medical Center, and Johns Hopkins All Children’s Hospital, to innovative companies such as Nordson Medical, Abbot, Chiesi, International Biomedical, Medtronic, Mead Johnson Nutrition, Phillips, Footprint Medical, Getinge, Masimo, General Electric, and Fisher&Paykel.

In addition to these interviews, the team actively participated in key neonatology and medical device conferences, including NEO, the Conference for Neonatology; Delphi, Neonatal Innovation Conference; Cool Topics in Neonatology; the 36th Annual Gravens Conference on the Environment of Care for High-risk Newborns; and the 2023 Design of Medical Device Conference. These conferences provided a platform for direct interaction with leading experts in neonatology, facilitating the needs validation and customer discovery process as well as further discussions on the latest trends, challenges, and innovations in neonatal care. Through workshops and networking sessions in these events, the team was able to validate their hypotheses, gather feedback on the Trinity Tube, and explore new perspectives on improving neonatal care. This blend of targeted interviews and active conference participation enriched the team's understanding of the clinical and practical needs within NICUs, ensuring a comprehensive approach to customer discovery.

The Trinity Tube's development is guided by a deep understanding of the neonatal care ecosystem, with clear value propositions that addresses unmet needs in preterm infant care.   Trinity Tube provides non-invasive vital signs monitoring and improved care for preterm infants in NICUs. It also optimizes respiratory support, infant comfort, parent to child bonding and skin integrity, while offering essential data for clinical decision-making and early detection of potential complications. The insights from the I-Corps Program interviews have highlighted the importance of continued engagement with all stakeholders, iterative product refinement, and strategic partnerships to achieve a successful market introduction and sustained impact on neonatal care practices. 


Last Modified: 09/09/2024
Modified by: Christopher G Rylander
